resource descriptions.descriptionText: PubMed is a searchable database of medical literature and lists journal articles that discuss Diabetic mastopathy. Click on the link to view a sample search on this topic.
Ely RA, Tse G, Simpson JF, Clarfeld R, Page D. Diabetic Mastopathy: Clinicopathologic Review. Anatomic Pathology. 2000; 113:541-545.
Medscape Reference provides information on this topic. You may need to register to view the medical textbook, but registration is free.

The Monarch Initiative brings together data about this condition from humans and other species to help physicians and biomedical researchers. Monarch’s tools are designed to make it easier to compare the signs and symptoms (phenotypes) of different diseases and discover common features. This initiative is a collaboration between several academic institutions across the world and is funded by the National Institutes of Health. Visit the website to explore the biology of this condition.

overviewQuestion.answerText: Diabetic mastopathy are noncancerous lesions in the breast most commonly diagnosed in premenopausal women with type 1 diabetes.[309][310][311] The cause of this condition is unknown.[309][310][311][312][314] Symptoms may include hard, irregular, easily movable, discrete, painless breast mass(es).[309][312][313]

basicQuestions.questionText: What are the symptoms of diabetic mastopathy?
basicQuestions.answerText: Common symptoms of diabetic mastopathy include hard, irregular, easily movable, discrete, painless breast mass(es). This condition can involve one or both breasts and can affect males and females. The breast lesions may not be palpable in some individuals. Individuals with diabetic mastopathy who have had insulin-requiring diabetes for a long time (>15 years) commonly have other diabetes complications as well (e.g., thyroid, eye, and joint involvement).[309][314][12822]

references.authors: Keyoung JA Zuurbier CA, Tsangaris TN, Azumi N, Makariou E
Ely KA, Tse G, Simpson JF, Clarfeld R, Page DL
Chan, CR et al

basicQuestions.answerText: The cause of diabetic mastopathy is unknown. Theories include an autoimmune reaction, genetic factors such as human leukocyte antigen (HLA) type, association with insulin therapy, and association with hyperglycemia.[309][310][314]

references.authors: Keyoung JA Zuurbier CA, Tsangaris TN, Azumi N, Makariou E
Honda M, Mori Y, Nishi T, Mizuguchi K, Ishibashi M
references.articleTitle: Diabetic mastopathy of bilateral breasts in an elderly Japanese woman with type 2 diabetes: a case report and a review of the literature in Japan

references.authors: Ely KA, Tse G, Simpson JF, Clarfeld R, Page DL

basicQuestions.answerText: The diagnosis of diabetic mastopathy should be considered in patients with long-standing insulin-dependent diabetes and a firm, mobile breast mass. Initial imaging studies may include mammography and ultrasound. While these methods can help to further differentiate the mass, they cannot provide a specific diagnosis of diabetic mastopathy with confident exclusion of malignancy. A core biopsy (utilizing a needle to remove a small cylinder of tissue) is often performed for a definitive diagnosis.[1708][1709][12822]

references.authors: Andrews-Tang D, Diamond AB, Rogers L, Butler D
references.articleTitle: Diabetic Mastopathy: Adjunctive Use of Ultrasound and Utility of Core Biopsy in Diagnosis

references.authors: Thorncroft K, Forsyth L, Desmond S, Audisio RA
references.articleTitle: The diagnosis and management of diabetic mastopathy.

references.authors: Chan, CR et al

basicQuestions.answerText: Typically, no treatment is necessary for diabetic mastopathy. Individuals with this condition should be advised about the condition and how to self examine the breasts to detect any changes in size and number of breast lumps. Patients should be routinely followed up with MRI or ultrasound and core biopsy if the lesions become clinically or radiologically suspicious. Lesions can be surgically removed for cosmetic reasons or if malignancy cannot be excluded.[1709][12822]

references.authors: Thorncroft K, Forsyth L, Desmond S, Audisio RA
references.articleTitle: The diagnosis and management of diabetic mastopathy.

references.authors: Chan, CR et al

gardCases.abbreviatedInquiry: I was diagnosed with diabetic mastopathy a few years ago and had a lumpectomy. Some of it was left behind, so not to cause disfigurement. Since that time I experience breast pain and throbbing a couple times a week. Is this pain connected to my breast disorder? Do you think it has spread, or simply reoccurred in other areas of the breast? Is pain normal? I worry about it becoming malignant also.

caseQuestions.answerText: Yes. Diabetic mastopathy can recur. In patients with recurrence, the recurrence tends to be in the same location involving more breast tissue than previously seen.[309][311]

references.authors: Keyoung JA Zuurbier CA, Tsangaris TN, Azumi N, Makariou E
Sotome K, Ohnishi T, Miyoshi R, Nakamaru M, Furukawa A, Miyazaki H, Morozumi K, Tanaka Y, Iri H
references.articleTitle: An Uncommon Case of Diabetic Mastopathy in Type II Non-Insulin Dependent Diabetes Mellitus

caseQuestions.questionText: Does diabetic mastopathy increase a person's risk for developing breast cancer?
caseQuestions.answerText: No. Research shows that diabetic mastopathy does not increase a person's risk for developing breast cancer.[309][310][312] The small number of reported cases which describe malignancy in patients with diabetic mastopathy are believed to be due to coincidence. At this time, there is no pathologic literature linking diabetic mastopathy with malignancy.[309][310][312][314][12822]

references.authors: Keyoung JA Zuurbier CA, Tsangaris TN, Azumi N, Makariou E
Honda M, Mori Y, Nishi T, Mizuguchi K, Ishibashi M

references.articleTitle: Diabetic mastopathy in type II diabetes mellitus

references.authors: Ely KA, Tse G, Simpson JF, Clarfeld R, Page DL
Chan, CR et al

caseQuestions.questionText: What are the symptoms of breast cancer?
caseQuestions.answerText: Common symptoms of breast cancer include, a change in how the breast or nipple feels, a lump or thickening in or near the breast or in the underarm area, nipple tenderness, a change in how the breast or nipple looks, a change in the size or shape of the breast, a nipple turned inward into the breast, scaly, red, or swollen skin of the breast, areola, or nipple. Other symptoms include ridges or pitting of the breast so that it looks like the skin of an orange and nipple discharge (fluid).[313]

references.articleTitle: What you need to know about breast cancer

caseQuestions.questionText: Is pain in the breast a symptom of breast cancer?
caseQuestions.answerText: Early breast cancer usually does not cause pain. Still, a person should see his/her health care provider about breast pain or any other symptom that does not go away. Most often, these symptoms are not due to cancer. Other health problems may also cause them. Any person with these symptoms should tell their doctor so that problems can be diagnosed and treated as early as possible.[313]

references.articleTitle: What you need to know about breast cancer

caseQuestions.questionText: Who should I talk to if I am concerned I may have breast cancer?
caseQuestions.answerText: If you are concerned that you may have breast cancer we recommend that you speak with your health care provider.

news.title: NIH-Supported Research Survey to Examine Impact of COVID-19 on Rare Diseases Community
news.description: The NIH-funded Rare Diseases Clinical Research Network (RDCRN) has launched an online research survey to find out how the COVID-19 pandemic is impacting individuals with rare diseases, their families and their caregivers. Your participation can help the rare disease research community shed light on the needs of people with rare diseases during this and other potential health crises, in addition to informing future research efforts. The survey must be completed by December 15, 2020.
